review.title: Robust Active Perception via Data-association aware Belief Space planning
review.abstract: We develop a belief space planning (BSP) approach that advances the state of the art by incorporating reasoning about data association (DA) within planning, while considering additional sources of uncertainty. Existing BSP approaches typically assume data association is given and perfect, an assumption that can be harder to justify while operating, in the presence of localization uncertainty, in ambiguous and perceptually aliased environments. In contrast, our data association aware belief space planning (DA-BSP) approach explicitly reasons about DA within belief evolution, and as such can better accommodate these challenging real world scenarios. In particular, we show that due to perceptual aliasing, the posterior belief becomes a mixture of probability distribution functions, and design cost functions that measure the expected level of ambiguity and posterior uncertainty. Using these and standard costs (e.g.~control penalty, distance to goal) within the objective function, yields a general framework that reliably represents action impact, and in particular, capable of active disambiguation. Our approach is thus applicable to robust active perception and autonomous navigation in perceptually aliased environments. We demonstrate key aspects in basic and realistic simulations.

sections.heading: 4.3 Aliased Multi-Floor Environment
sections.text: Since the inclusion of data associations implies that (at least theoretically) an exponential increase in the number of unimodal beliefs at the back is maintained, we evaluated DA-GNP in a simple but real scene by using a real Pioneer robot in a three-story aliassociated environment (see Fig. 5a), with a similar goal of defining ground and position. If the robot does not think about perception aliasing, it takes greedy measures (in terms of control costs and position uncertainty) and fails to be unambiguous, while DA-GNP successfully approaches planning with data association, as shown in Fig. 5b. Although not observed here, GNP cannot guarantee an optimal global solution (without control and uncertainty costs), and similarly DA-GNP cannot provide a global minimum cost path for a full definition - a problem known as NP-hard [10].

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: Such an assumption, however, is less appropriate in view of the uncertainty of localization, while it operates in ambiguous environments in which two scenes might look similar when viewed from appropriate viewpoints. In this work, we have developed a data association-conscious approach to faith planning (DA-BSP) that loosens the aforementioned assumption. Our framework rigorously takes into account aspects of data association within the BSP, taking into account various sources of uncertainty (uncertainty in robotic movement, perception and possibly in the observed environment). As such, it is able to better deal with ambiguous perceptual situations by appropriately calculating faith expansion and expected costs arising from candidate actions, and, in particular, using it for active disambiguity. Thanks to this connection inherent in planning, DA-BSP regards data association as parsimonious and a simple threshold for an explicit application of the data association-conscious faith planning as part of real planning.
